metadata.case_name: William Jacks Co. Employees Union, Madras v. William Jacks Co. Ltd., Madras

facts.text: Appeal by special leave against Award dated March 9, 1968 of Industrial Tribunal, Madras in Industrial Dispute No. II of 1957 relating to bonus payment under Payment of Bonus Act, 1965.
Appellant (William Jacks Co. Employees Union, Madras) claimed bonus at maximum 20% of annual wages for calendar years 1964 and 1965.
Respondent (William Jacks Co. Ltd., Madras) claimed no available surplus, liability limited to minimum 4% of wages.
Respondent is a branch of William Jacks Co. Ltd. registered in England, Head Office in London; branches in Calcutta (Regional Head Office), Bombay, and Madras.

Company business: engineers, manufacturers, representatives, general merchants; buys locally manufactured machinery and sells to private/public sectors; income from sale of imported/indigenous goods at profit.
Madras branch earns commission credited by London Office on direct shipments and on sale of indigenous products, repairs, servicing.
Company filed balance-sheets, profit/loss accounts, calculations of available surplus per Act and Schedules showing no surplus beyond 4%.
Tribunal rejected challenges to calculations and based Award on Company's accounts.
Direct commission: Rs. 8,80,504 in 1964 and Rs. 7,46,391 in 1965 included in Profit and Loss Account under 'Commission'; credited in Madras branch accounts.
Handling charges included by London Head Office in invoices for goods sent to Madras; recoverable from customers; not shown as expenditure; not part of administrative overhead.
Directors and General Managers Office expenses in Calcutta: Rs. 44,768 in 1964 and Rs. 50,848 in 1965; allocable to Madras branch as administrative overhead.
Interest charged by London Office on advances to Madras branch: Rs. 1,00,657 in 1964 and Rs. 1,65,255 in 1965.
Jax Board Factory expenses: Rs. 11,747 in 1964 and Rs. 7,251 in 1965; factory had no production but did not completely cease functioning; actual expenses certified by auditors.
Provisions for gratuity, furlough salary, passage, service, commission: made for accrued liabilities based on service up to relevant years.
Income-tax calculated without accounting for bonus payable under Act.

legal_issues.text: Whether direct commission of Rs. 40,000 received by London Office for Madras branch requires add back to gross profits.
Whether handling charges included in invoices by London Office require add back as double deduction of administrative overhead.
Whether Directors and General Managers Office expenses in Calcutta require add back.
Whether interest charged by London Head Office on advances to Madras branch (Rs. 1,00,657 in 1964, Rs. 1,65,255 in 1965) is legitimate expenditure deductible in calculating available surplus.
Whether Jax Board Factory expenses require add back as factory ceased functioning.
Whether provisions for gratuity and other contingencies are reserves under item 2(c) Second Schedule requiring add back.
Whether income-tax deduction should account for bonus payable under Act.

petitioner_arguments.text: Add back estimated Rs. 40,000 direct commission paid by manufacturers to London Office for Madras branch benefit.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Payment of Bonus Act, 1965 (calculation of gross profits)

petitioner_arguments.text: Add back handling charges as double deduction after administrative overhead under item 6(e) Second Schedule.
Add back Directors and General Managers Office expenses in Calcutta (Rs. 44,768/1964, Rs. 50,848/1965).
Disallow interest on advances from London Office per proviso to item 1(iii) Third Schedule.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Proviso to item 1(iii) Third Schedule to Act

petitioner_arguments.text: Add back Jax Board Factory expenses as factory ceased functioning.
Add back provision for gratuity/other contingencies as reserves under item 2(c) Second Schedule.
Calculate income-tax after deducting bonus payable.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Sections 6(c), 7; Payment of Bonus Amendment Act 8 of 1969

respondent_arguments.text: Direct commission already included in Profit and Loss Account under 'Commission'.
Handling charges not expenditure; added to cost of goods and recovered from customers; not administrative overhead.
Calcutta office expenses allocable to Madras branch as administrative overhead; proved by witness.
Interest on advances is legitimate expenditure; presumption under section 23 as audited.
Jax Board Factory expenses actual and certified; factory not completely ceased.
Provisions for gratuity etc. are for accrued liabilities, not reserves.
Income-tax calculated ignoring bonus per Metal Box case.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Metal Box Co. of India Ltd. v. Their Workmen

court_reasoning.text: Direct commission already included in gross profits per witness evidence; no cross-examination or contrary evidence.
Handling charges not expenditure or administrative overhead; added to invoice costs and recovered from customers.
Calcutta expenses are allocable administrative overhead; no contrary evidence.

No creditor-debtor relationship between Head Office and branch of same company; interest is not legitimate expenditure; add back Rs. 1,00,657 (1964) and Rs. 1,65,255 (1965); proviso to item 1 Third Schedule supports view.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Section 23 presumption limited; interest wrongly shown as expenditure.

court_reasoning.text: Jax Board expenses actual per auditors; factory not completely ceased.
Provisions for accrued liabilities (gratuity etc.), not reserves; distinguished per Metal Box case definition of provision vs. reserve.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Not add back under item 2(c) Second Schedule.

court_reasoning.text: Income-tax calculated ignoring bonus per Metal Box; amendment Act 8/1969 does not alter this.

holdings.text: Tribunal calculations correct except interest on Head Office advances to be added back to available surplus.
No creditor-debtor relation between company offices; interest not deductible expenditure.
Provisions for gratuity etc. are provisions for known liabilities, not reserves.

precedents_cited.case_name: Metal Box Co. of India Ltd. v. Their Workmen
precedents_cited.relevance: Distinction between provision and reserve; income-tax calculation ignoring bonus.

statutes_cited.name: Payment of Bonus Act, 1965 (No. 21 of 1965)
statutes_cited.relevance: Calculation of gross profits, available surplus, deductions for prior charges, presumptions on accounts, treatment of interest/advances for foreign companies.

statutes_cited.name: Payment of Bonus Amendment Act, 8 of 1969
statutes_cited.relevance: Amendments do not alter income-tax calculation method.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed in part; Tribunal correct except add back of interest paid on advances from Head Office (Rs. 1,00,657 for 1964, Rs. 1,65,255 for 1965) to available surplus; calculation left to Tribunal.
outcome.relief_granted: Add back interest to available surplus for bonus calculation and set on/off.

key_quotes.text: "No relationship of creditor and debtor can exist between two different Offices of the same Company."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core reasoning for disallowing interest deduction.

key_quotes.text: "The distinction between a provision and a reserve is in commercial accountancy fairly well-known."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains why gratuity provisions not added back, citing Metal Box.
